content.webTitle: Friday briefing: Peterborough – Labour shows Farage the exit

fields.headline: Friday briefing: Peterborough – Labour shows Farage the exit
fields.bodyText: Top story: ‘Brexit party has been rejected here’ Hello, Warren Murray here with matters of moment. Labour has held on to Peterborough, defeating predictions of a first byelection victory to Nigel Farage’s Brexit party. The new MP, Lisa Forbes, said: “The fact that the Brexit party have been rejected here in Peterborough shows that the politics of division will not win.” Farage left the count through a back door minutes before the result was announced. Forbes won 10,484 votes, beating the Brexit party’s Mike Greene who took 9,801 votes – a margin of 683. The Conservatives were beaten into third place with 7,243 votes. Turnout was 48%. After the result, Jeremy Corbyn said the Tories had been pushed to the margins because of their cuts and disastrous handling of Brexit. “I look forward to welcoming Lisa to parliament next week,” he said. The victory will help Corbyn in his fight with critics within the party who want him to change course and emphatically back a second Brexit referendum. Follow all the latest on the byelection result and the day in politics at our live blog. * * * Another wheel falls off Brexit – The HMRC official in charge of delivering “frictionless” border arrangements, including emergency plans in the event of no deal, has quit. The departure of Karen Wheeler is seen as increasing the risk of a chaotic no-deal Brexit on 31 October. Today, as Theresa May steps down to become only a caretaker PM, contenders to replace her are being warned that they will probably face an immediate confidence vote in the Commons. The government survives on a handful of DUP votes, and some Conservative MPs have deep reservations about serving under a PM who is prepared to leave the EU without a Brexit deal on 31 October, such as Boris Johnson or Dominic Raab (Gaby Hinsliff highlights that the latter seems prepared to suspend parliament to ram a no-deal Brexit through). Labour sources have said they believe government whips may be planning an early recess, before the Tory leadership contest is decided in the week of 22 July. Downing Street has said May “fully expects that the house will ensure it is sitting when a new prime minister is appointed”. * * * NHS failing on diversity – The proportion of black and minority ethnic people in the most senior roles at NHS trusts in England has dropped from 15% in 2010 to just 8%, research shows. The proportion of women in those posts has also fallen from 47% in 2002 to only 38% – fuelling claims that the health service is going backwards on diversity and inclusion. The 38% of chair and non-executive director roles filled by women stands in stark contrast to 77% of the NHS workforce being female. The report by the NHS Confederation blames the gaps in female and BME representation on the abolition in 2012 of the NHS Appointments Commission and the move, begun during Tony Blair’s premiership, to let NHS trusts become semi-independent foundation trusts. The confederation is calling for an urgent overhaul of the appointments procedures. * * * Transphobia row on campus – All 12 members of Edinburgh University’s LGBT+ committee have resigned in a protest against university authorities after a feminist meeting on Wednesday night that featured speakers who have criticised proposed reforms to transgender rights. The campaigner Julie Bindel was allegedly verbally abused and lunged at by a transgender activist following the meeting about the future of women’s sex-based rights. Bindel underlined that she had been talking about male violence, not transgender issues, at the event. The university row reflects broader tensions around proposed changes to gender recognition legislation in Scotland. Lucy Hunter-Blackman, another panellist and an Edinburgh University researcher, has been critical of proposed changes to the next census around the question of biological sex. * * * Embezzling MP jailed – The former MP for Glasgow East, Natalie McGarry, has been sent to jail for 18 months for stealing more than £25,000 from Scottish independence campaign groups. Women for Independence (WfI), one of the groups, expressed frustration at the lack of alternatives to prison available to the courts. McGarry pleaded guilty in April to taking money from WfI and the SNP’s Glasgow regional association. The court heard of McGarry’s mental ill health starting before she entered parliament in 2015, including depression and anxiety as well as postpartum depression. McGarry, 37, broke down in the dock as her lawyer told the court she had suffered a miscarriage this week. Labour’s Margaret Curran, who lost her seat to McGarry in the 2015 general election, said: “Natalie and I had our differences but this seems such a harsh sentence for a mother of a young child. This must make the case for sentencing reform.” * * * ‘Huawei is shoddy’ – Don’t be surprised if and when China’s bellicose state press latches on to comments from within spy agency GCHQ that the telecoms company Huawei is a maker of “shoddy” systems. “The security is objectively worse [than other companies’] and we need to cope with that,” said Ian Levy, technical director of Britain’s National Cyber Security Centre. The US has led allegations that Beijing can use Huawei’s equipment for espionage. British officials have also raised concerns about security issues but said they can manage the risks and have seen no evidence of spying. Asked about how Huawei compares with its competitors, Levy told a London conference: “Certainly nothing is perfect, certainly Huawei is shoddy, the others are less shoddy.” Britain’s National Security Council decided in April to block Huawei from all core parts of its future 5G network but to give it restricted access to non-core parts. Today in Focus podcast: Goodbye to Maybot John Crace, Guardian sketch writer, first coined the term “the Maybot” in 2016 after a car crash interview had the PM robotically repeating the same phrases. Today, as she steps down as Conservative leader, Crace discusses who might take over. Plus: the Guardian’s Suzanne Wrack on the start of the Fifa Women’s World Cup. Lunchtime read: Summer hit is the new Christmas single In 2013 it was the relentless funk of Daft Punk’s Get Lucky. Last year it was a three-way tie between Calvin Harris and Dua Lipa’s One Kiss, Drake’s God’s Plan and George Ezra’s Shotgun – those songs went on to become the biggest sellers of the year. In the UK, it used to be all about the Christmas No 1. But as we purchase less music directly and swing behind streaming, the summer, stretching from as early as April to late September, is much more lucrative. So what alchemy brings about a Shotgun or Despacito – and who are this year’s contenders? Sport The biggest Women’s World Cup in history is kicking off at the Parc des Princes today but in Paris there is not the air of anticipation you would expect. Gareth Southgate has thrown his support behind John Stones and Ross Barkley after dreadful errors in extra-time condemned England to their latest semi-final defeat to the Netherlands. In the Cricket World Cup, Australia beat West Indies by 15 runs at Trent Bridge in a topsy-turvy match to which not only players but the umpires contributed quixotically. England Women got their summer off to a brilliant start at Leicester, hitting their highest one-day international total against West Indies – 318 for nine – before bowling them out for 110 to finish with a 208-run win. At the French Open, the 17-year-old Amanda Anisimova produced a stunning performance to defeat defending champion Simona Halep in the quarter-finals. Meanwhile, Rafael Nadal still looks unbeatable on the red clay of Paris but the 38-year-old Roger Federer believes he can end his run. Lewis Hamilton has expressed his confidence going into the Canadian Grand Prix, as Mercedes bring their first upgraded engine to the race. And Amir Khan has defended the choice of location for his next fight in the face of human rights concerns by claiming Saudi Arabia is undergoing significant change. Business Asian shares have mostly been higher on investor optimism about a possible trade deal between the US and Mexico before tariffs take effect. The Nikkei, Australia’s S&P/ASX 200, South Korea’s Kospi and the Hang Seng made gains while the Shanghai Composite fell. A modest Wall Street rally gained strength in the final hour of trading after Bloomberg reported that the US was considering delaying a 5% tariff on Mexican goods. The pound is worth $1.269 and €1.126 while the FTSE should open around a quarter of a percent higher. The papers The same photo is splashed across many of the front pages today: six-year-old George Sayer holding hands with veteran John Quinn during D-day commemorations. Among them the Daily Mail, which has the headline “Thank you for our freedom”, the Mirror: “Freedom in our hands”, the Express: “Thank you for giving me my future”, the i: “Thank you” and the Sun, though its lead story is that two men are considering suing Camelot unless it pays their £4m scratchcard jackpot: “It could be sue”. The Guardian also has a photograph of a D-day veteran but the lead story is “NHS drive for diversity in key roles ‘going backwards’”. The Telegraph similarly has a D-day pic but its main story is: “Only Boris can fight off Farage, polls finds”. The Times has a picture of Donald Trump and Emmanuel Macron watching D-day commemorations, but its main story is: “MPs fear Qeeen will be dragged into Brexit”. The FT steers clear of D-day altogether, instead splashing on a row between the prime minister and her chancellor ahead of her last day in office: “Hammond puts up barriers over May’s plan for £10bn parting gift”. Sign up The Guardian Morning Briefing is delivered to thousands of inboxes bright and early every weekday. If you are not already receiving it by email, you can sign up here. For more news: www.theguardian.com
